Ultimately the viewer has the final decision of whether or not they want to see the film or at least approve of it, and that's the way it should be. I think this is more about personal preference. I just prefer movies that don't have a political agenda--that's my personal preference. But I'd never say "movies shouldn't have messages." Indeed, the message is often the most moving part of a film. I tend to like films that move people from a human standpoint and inspire. But if a film has a blatant or veiled message of politics, it tends to turn me off because I know it's just a soapbox. An example is the movie adaptation of John Grisham's novel Runaway Jury. I've read the book AND seen the movie. The movie ended up being a soapbox anti-gun political message--whereas the book was NOTHING like that. The movie was basically a political soapbox masquarading as a basic courtroom-drama movie. Now, if that's the film the writers and producers want to make--so be it. It's their movie to make. But it doesn't fall within my preferences and as a result I think of it and refer to it as a political soapbox movie.

My wife and I finally rented Brokeback Mountain last weekend.
 
 It was one of the best movies I've seen in my life.
 
 Very rarely have I been emotionally moved to the level that I was after watching it. The story and the way it's told are second to none. The scenery and backdrop to the movie are extraordinary (filmed in my backyard basically), the lead actors are all excellent, subtle and yet very powerful performances, and the directing of the picture is truely superb. Kudos to Ang Lee for letting the story tell itself, and setting the mood and atmospere of the picture so beautifully.
 
 This really is an amazing story of love and the human condition. If anyone can watch this movie and not be moved by the experiences of the characters, I'd question their humanity.
 
 I know that this film has been highly politicized, but at no time does it bludgeon or even lecture the audience on "gay rights". The sexual tension is touched on, and there are two brief homosexual scenes, but the viewer is certainly not pouned on the head by it, it's PG13 type stuff. It merely tells a story that is so well written and so real, that you can't help feel for the characters and their plight. There's no question that it left me deeply saddened, and angry/embarassed about the way our society has, and continues to treat, homosexuals. I was also saddened at the effects this had on the other victims in the story - the wives and children of the two men.
 
 Anyhoo, I just had to post something after actually watching the movie. Two thumbs up. It really is a movie that everyone should see IMHO, regardless of your position on homosexuality. The movie is far more than that.
